Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - C Team Baseball
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - C Team Baseball at Gallup High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - C Team Baseball plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Gallup High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - C Team Baseball expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - C Team Baseball supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - C Team Baseball may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Gallup High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - JV Girls Basketball
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - JV Girls Basketball role at Ramah High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - JV Girls Basketball coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Ramah High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - JV Girls Basketball reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Ramah High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - JV Girls Basketball may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - JV Girls Basketball monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - JV Girls Basketball must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Ramah High School.

The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Assistant Track role at Ramah High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Assistant Track is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Ramah High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Assistant Track listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Assistant Track encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Assistant Track follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Ramah High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Assistant Track at Ramah High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track role at Thoreau High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Thoreau High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Thoreau High School, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the 2025-2026 SY - Athletic Coach - Head Track at Thoreau High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Assistant coach Volleyball position at Farmington High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Assistant coach Volleyball prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Farmington High School, the Assistant coach Volleyball works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Assistant coach Volleyball encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant coach Volleyball at Farmington High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Assistant coach Boys Basketball at Piedra Vista High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant coach Boys Basketball is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Piedra Vista High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant coach Boys Basketball helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant coach Boys Basketball works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Piedra Vista High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Piedra Vista High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant coach Boys Basketball reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant coach Boys Basketball role at Piedra Vista High School.

The Assistant Varsity Coach will supervise practice, contests, travel, equipment and other requirements related to the sport they are coaching. They are to ensure student safety and eligibility for participating in the sport. Supervisors are the head coach, athletic director, and principal. Shared authority with the head coach over all players and season related activities. Job Responsibilities: Supervise students during practices and games including locker room, around the building, and gym area Ensure participants maintain acceptable standards of behavior and decorum. Assist in conducting and supervising practices throughout the sport season. Complete other tasks as assigned by the head coach. Qualifications: Appropriate National and/or State Coaching Certifications. Physical Requirements: Sitting, standing, lifting and carrying (up to 50 pounds), reaching, squatting, kneeling, prolonged typing, physical ability to type on a keyboard terminal, and moving equipment may be required. Equipment/Technology Handled: Must know how to properly operate or be willing to learn to operate equipment related to the sport, computer and other equipment as needed. Work Environment: Must be able to work within various degrees of noise, temperature, and air quality. Interruptions of work are routine. Flexibility and patience are required. Must be self-motivated and able to complete job assignment without direct supervision. After hour work may be required. Terms of Employment: Salary and work calendar established yearly by the district.

Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Volunteer Assistant Coach Track at Hermosa Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Volunteer Assistant Coach Track is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Hermosa Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Volunteer Assistant Coach Track helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Volunteer Assistant Coach Track works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Hermosa Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Hermosa Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Volunteer Assistant Coach Track reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Volunteer Assistant Coach Track role at Hermosa Middle School.

From a competitive standpoint, the Head Coach - Cheerleading, JV Grade AHS is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.

The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Alamogordo High School, the Head Coach - Cheerleading, JV Grade AHS is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Head Coach - Cheerleading, JV Grade AHS at Alamogordo High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The 7th & 8th Boys Basketball Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the 7th & 8th Boys Basketball Coach role at Carson Middle School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Head Cross Country Coach - Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Cross Country Coach - Middle School role at Carson Middle School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Head Cross Country Coach - Middle School coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Carson Middle School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Head Cross Country Coach - Middle School reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Carson Middle School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Head Cross Country Coach - Middle School may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Head Cross Country Coach - Middle School monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Head Cross Country Coach - Middle School must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Carson Middle School.

The Middle School Track Coach at Eagle Valley Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Middle School Track Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Eagle Valley Middle School, the Middle School Track Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Middle School Track Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Eagle Valley Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Middle School Track Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Assistant Basketball Coach - Girls at Carson High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Eagle Valley Middle School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. The 7th & 8th Boys Basketball Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. The High School Girls Tennis Coach at Carson High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the High School Girls Tennis Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Carson High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The High School Girls Tennis Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The High School Girls Tennis Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Carson High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Carson High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the High School Girls Tennis Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the High School Girls Tennis Coach role at Carson High School.

The Wrestling Coach - Carson Middle School position at Carson Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Wrestling Coach - Carson Middle School works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Wrestling Coach - Carson Middle School at Carson Middle School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Carson Middle School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Wrestling Coach - Carson Middle School encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Wrestling Coach - Carson Middle School is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Wrestling Coach - Carson Middle School position at Carson Middle School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Assistant Softball Coach role at Carson High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Assistant Softball Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Carson High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Assistant Softball Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Assistant Softball Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Assistant Softball Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Carson High School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Assistant Softball Coach at Carson High School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The Girls Volleyball Coach position at Eagle Valley Middle School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Girls Volleyball Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Eagle Valley Middle School, the Girls Volleyball Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Girls Volleyball Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Girls Volleyball Coach at Eagle Valley Middle School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Volleyball Coach at Schurz Elementary School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Volleyball Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Schurz Elementary School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Volleyball Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Schurz Elementary School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.

At its core, the Dance Advisor/Coach at Mineral County High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

DISTINGUISHING FEATURES OF THE CLASS: Provides for the care, prevention and treatment of athletic injuries and/or improves physical fitness of athletes for participation in various sports programs. Under the general supervision of a licensed physician and the District Athletic Director, incumbents of this position are responsible for the care and prevention and treatment of athletic injuries involving student athletes. In accordance with Section 8532 of New York State Education Law the practice of the profession of athletic training is defined as the application of principles and methods of conditioning athletes, preventing and treating athletic injuries through the use of appropriate preventative and supportive devices, under the direction of a physician, recognizing and evaluating athletic injuries, administering first aid and emergency care, developing and implementing treatment and rehabilitation programs for athletic injuries under the direction of a physician and the planning and implementation of programs and services to help prevent athletic injuries. Incumbents are responsible for the record keeping of athletic injuries and treatments. Does related work as required.

Dublin Scioto High School (Dublin, OH) is seeking a Head Varsity Boys Soccer Coach. The head coach will be responsible for the overall coordination and leadership of the Dublin Scioto’s Boys Soccer program and must possess strong communication, organization, and leadership skills. Candidates with experience as head coach or assistant coach at the high school or collegiate level are preferred. A current background check is required and applicants must obtain all required coaching certifications and have a current Pupil Activity Permit through the Ohio Department of Education (ODE). All applicants should send a letter of interest and resume with references to Athletic Director Nick Magistrate at magistrate_nick@dublinschools.net. For questions or additional information, please contact Nick Magistrate at 614-717-2468. Applications will be accepted through Friday, January 2nd, 2026, or until the position has been filled.

The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Lincoln High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Head Boys Tennis Coach at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined) is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Head Boys Tennis Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At MSE/MSS/MSW (combined), coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Head Boys Tennis Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Head Boys Tennis Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined) operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent MSE/MSS/MSW (combined) with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Head Boys Tennis Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Head Boys Tennis Coach role at MSE/MSS/MSW (combined).

The Assistant Boys Soccer Coach at Lincoln High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Assistant Boys Soccer Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Lincoln High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Assistant Boys Soccer Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Assistant Boys Soccer Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Assistant Boys Soccer Coach at Lincoln High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The Assistant Football Coach position at Lincoln High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Assistant Football Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Lincoln High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Assistant Football Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Assistant Football Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Football Coach role at Lincoln High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The WCHS Football Head Coach position at West Clermont High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the WCHS Football Head Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At West Clermont High School, the WCHS Football Head Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The WCHS Football Head Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the WCHS Football Head Coach at West Clermont High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The Softball - Assistant Coach position at Mentor Exempted Village School District is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Softball - Assistant Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Softball - Assistant Coach at Mentor Exempted Village School District sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Mentor Exempted Village School District, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Softball - Assistant Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Softball - Assistant Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Softball - Assistant Coach position at Mentor Exempted Village School District is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.
Job.CompanyDescription: Mentor Exempted Village School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Coach-Paid role at Upper Arlington Schools emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Coach-Paid coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Upper Arlington Schools, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Coach-Paid reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Upper Arlington Schools at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Coach-Paid may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Coach-Paid monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Coach-Paid must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Upper Arlington Schools.

Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Head 7th Grade Softball Coach role at Jones Middle School.

Job.JobDescription:
The Adjunct Assistant Athletic Coach role at Oklahoma City Public Sch. is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Adjunct Assistant Athletic Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Oklahoma City Public Sch., teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Adjunct Assistant Athletic Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Oklahoma City Public Sch., the Adjunct Assistant Athletic Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Adjunct Assistant Athletic Coach at Oklahoma City Public Sch. is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
The Adjunct Head Athletic Coach position at Oklahoma City Public Sch. is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Adjunct Head Athletic Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Adjunct Head Athletic Coach at Oklahoma City Public Sch. sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Oklahoma City Public Sch., athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Adjunct Head Athletic Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Adjunct Head Athletic Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Adjunct Head Athletic Coach position at Oklahoma City Public Sch. is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Assistant Girls Soccer at Moore High is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Coach - Assistant Girls Soccer are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Moore High use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Coach - Assistant Girls Soccer recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Coach - Assistant Girls Soccer collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Coach - Assistant Girls Soccer maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Moore High. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.Location: Moore High 300 N. Eastern Moore, OK 73160

Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Assistant Boys Track at Southmoore High is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Coach - Assistant Boys Track is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Southmoore High, the Coach - Assistant Boys Track helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Coach - Assistant Boys Track may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Southmoore High well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Coach - Assistant Boys Track follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.Location: Southmoore High 2901 S. Santa Fe Moore, OK 73160

The Coach - Head Volleyball role at Southmoore High is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Coach - Head Volleyball is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Southmoore High are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Coach - Head Volleyball listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Coach - Head Volleyball encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Coach - Head Volleyball follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Southmoore High, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.

The Head Volleyball Coach at NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. The Assistant Fast Pitch Coach position at NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.

At NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL, the Assistant Fast Pitch Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Assistant Fast Pitch Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant Fast Pitch Coach at NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The 25-26 Assistant Volleyball Coach position at WHITTIER MIDDLE SCHOOL is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the 25-26 Assistant Volleyball Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. At WHITTIER MIDDLE SCHOOL, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it.
