Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Track Coach - WAMS (2 positions) at Waynesboro Area Middle School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Assistant Track Coach - WAMS (2 positions) plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Waynesboro Area Middle School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Assistant Track Coach - WAMS (2 positions) expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Assistant Track Coach - WAMS (2 positions) supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Assistant Track Coach - WAMS (2 positions) may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Waynesboro Area Middle School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription:
The Interscholastic Strength and Conditioning 1st Assistant at Fox Chapel Area High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Interscholastic Strength and Conditioning 1st Assistant is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Fox Chapel Area High School, the Interscholastic Strength and Conditioning 1st Assistant helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Interscholastic Strength and Conditioning 1st Assistant may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Fox Chapel Area High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Interscholastic Strength and Conditioning 1st Assistant follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

The Middle School Baseball Assistant Coach at Dorseyville Middle School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Middle School Baseball Assistant Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Dorseyville Middle School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Middle School Baseball Assistant Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Middle School Baseball Assistant Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Middle School Baseball Assistant Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Dorseyville Middle School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Middle School Field Hockey Head Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Middle School Field Hockey Head Coach at Dorseyville Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Middle School Field Hockey Head Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Dorseyville Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Middle School Field Hockey Head Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Middle School Field Hockey Head Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Dorseyville Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Dorseyville Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Middle School Field Hockey Head Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Middle School Field Hockey Head Coach role at Dorseyville Middle School.

When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 7th Grade Baseball Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 7th Grade Baseball Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Sandy Run Middle School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
Job.CompanyDescription: School District of Upper Dublin coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The 8th Grade Softball Coach, SRMS role at Sandy Run Middle School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the 8th Grade Softball Coach, SRMS is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Sandy Run Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The 8th Grade Softball Coach, SRMS sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Sandy Run Middle School, the 8th Grade Softball Coach, SRMS is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the 8th Grade Softball Coach, SRMS at Sandy Run Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.CompanyDescription: School District of Upper Dublin coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The JV Softball Coach at Upper Dublin High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the JV Softball Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Upper Dublin High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The JV Softball Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The JV Softball Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Upper Dublin High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Upper Dublin High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the JV Softball Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the JV Softball Coach role at Upper Dublin High School.
Job.CompanyDescription: School District of Upper Dublin coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The JV Football Coach, SRMS position at Sandy Run Middle School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the JV Football Coach, SRMS prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Sandy Run Middle School, the JV Football Coach, SRMS works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The JV Football Coach, SRMS encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the JV Football Coach, SRMS at Sandy Run Middle School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Tennis Coach - Cleveland HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription: Posting Timeline This job is open until filled. Applications will be reviewed as received. Portland Public Schools reserves the right to make a hiring decision at any point during the posting period. Position Details DISTRICT MISSION: At PPS, our goal is that by the end of elementary, middle and high school every student by name is meeting or exceeding academic standards and is fully prepared to make productive life decisions. DISTRICT PROFILE: To obtain more information about our district, schools, learning environment and programs, please go to https://www.pps.net/Domain/265. Key points of the job description for a Varsity Head Coach: High ethical and professional standards. Direct a successful grade 9-12 program and oversee all facets of an entire community youth program. 3 years of High School coaching experience Be a role model for high school student-athletes. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports by encouraging student-athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program. Lead student-athletes in the support of other Portland Public Schools athletics and activities. The Head Coach will be responsible for the following: Manage all aspects of the high school program including training, practice schedules and routines. Hire and oversee a staff of assistant coaches Provide regular communication with parents/families Regularly track the academic progress of all student athletes in the program and facilitate necessary supports to ensure their academic eligibility. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports and encourage athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program for athletics. All new hired coaches will need to complete the following prior to employment: NFHS/ASEP Certification First Aid Card (CPR and AED trained) District Fingerprinting/Criminal check Completion of OSAA Concussion Test Completion of ODE Steroid Test Completion of OSAA Heat Test *Head Up Football *Cheer and Dance/Drill Spirit Safety Training Completion of Portland Public School District paperwork and trainings. Applicant will be asked to apply online at our website and include the following: A cover letter detailing your experience. A current resume. A minimum of three letters of recommendation/reference. All PPS job offers are contingent on the satisfactory completion of a background check, including fingerprinting and criminal records. Salary Range - $6100.00 to $10,000.00 * There is no compensation for summer and out of season workouts. Portland Public Schools (PPS) is seeking talented people from diverse backgrounds and experiences to lead change and inspire PPS students. At PPS, every employee, despite having different roles, is an educator. We hope to attract talented educators who model the core PPS Educator Essentials. With the District’s focus on eliminating systemic racism and its adverse impact on student learning, we seek to hire individuals who bring to our district a deep commitment to racial equity and social justice. The District is committed to equal opportunity and nondiscrimination in all its educational and employment activities. The District prohibits discrimination based on perceived or actual race; national or ethnic origin; color; sex; religion; age; sexual orientation; gender expression or identity; pregnancy; marital status; veteran’s status; familial status; economic status or source of income; mental or physical disability or perceived disability; or military service. 504 Coordinator: Marquita Guzman,mguzman@pps.net, 971-393-8633 ADA Coordinator: Jey Buno, jbuno@pps.net, 503-916-3360 Civil Rights Director: Dr. Bobby Cruz, bcruz@pps.net, 503-839-3660 Accessibility Statement Conflict/Complaint Resolution Process
Job.Sport: Football, Tennis, Track & Field, Dance Team/Cheer

Position Type: Athletics/Activities/Athletic Coach - High School Softball
Date Posted: 12/17/2025
Location: Hiroshi Miyamura High School
Date Available: SY2025-2026
Closing Date: Open Until Filled
Title: Athletic Coach – JV Softball Work Location: Hiroshi Miyamura High School Contract Length: Spring Sport Minimum Salary: $5,000.00 Maximum Salary: $5,000.00
*Internal applicants MUST attach a signed Permission to Coach Form to application*
ATHLETIC COACHING LICENSE, 7-12
High School Diploma or Equivalency AND Must hold or have the ability to obtain an Athletic Coaching License (https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/bureaus/licensure/how-to-apply/athletic-coach-7-12/) from the New Mexico Public Education Department as well as completing the Fundamentals of Coaching online exam offered through the New Mexico Activities Association. (www.nmact.org)
QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions.
REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals.
SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal.
JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc.
Work with students interested in sports, provide necessary practice support and advice for a team to be successful against opposing teams in a sports season. Teach and enforce rules and regulations. Involves work on evenings and weekends.

Job.JobDescription:
The District Pole Vault Coach at Arlington Central Office is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the District Pole Vault Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Arlington Central Office, the District Pole Vault Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The District Pole Vault Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Arlington Central Office well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The District Pole Vault Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.CompanyDescription: Springfield City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Girls Track position at NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Assistant Girls Track prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL, the Assistant Girls Track works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Assistant Girls Track encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant Girls Track at NORMAN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Tennis Coach - Benson HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription: Posting Timeline This job is open until filled. Applications will be reviewed as received. Portland Public Schools reserves the right to make a hiring decision at any point during the posting period. Position Details DISTRICT MISSION: At PPS, our goal is that by the end of elementary, middle and high school every student by name is meeting or exceeding academic standards and is fully prepared to make productive life decisions. DISTRICT PROFILE: To obtain more information about our district, schools, learning environment and programs, please go to https://www.pps.net/Domain/265. Key points of the job description for a Varsity Head Coach: High ethical and professional standards. Direct a successful grade 9-12 program and oversee all facets of an entire community youth program. 3 years of High School coaching experience Be a role model for high school student-athletes. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports by encouraging student-athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program. Lead student-athletes in the support of other Portland Public Schools athletics and activities. The Head Coach will be responsible for the following: Manage all aspects of the high school program including training, practice schedules and routines. Hire and oversee a staff of assistant coaches Provide regular communication with parents/families Regularly track the academic progress of all student athletes in the program and facilitate necessary supports to ensure their academic eligibility. Cooperate with other school-sponsored sports and encourage athletes to compete in other programs. Develop and implement an off-season program for athletics. All new hired coaches will need to complete the following prior to employment: NFHS/ASEP Certification First Aid Card (CPR and AED trained) District Fingerprinting/Criminal check Completion of OSAA Concussion Test Completion of ODE Steroid Test Completion of OSAA Heat Test *Head Up Football *Cheer and Dance/Drill Spirit Safety Training Completion of Portland Public School District paperwork and trainings. Applicant will be asked to apply online at our website and include the following: A cover letter detailing your experience. A current resume. A minimum of three letters of recommendation/reference. All PPS job offers are contingent on the satisfactory completion of a background check, including fingerprinting and criminal records. Salary Range - $6100.00 to $10,000.00 * There is no compensation for summer and out of season workouts. Portland Public Schools (PPS) is seeking talented people from diverse backgrounds and experiences to lead change and inspire PPS students. At PPS, every employee, despite having different roles, is an educator. We hope to attract talented educators who model the core PPS Educator Essentials. With the District’s focus on eliminating systemic racism and its adverse impact on student learning, we seek to hire individuals who bring to our district a deep commitment to racial equity and social justice. The District is committed to equal opportunity and nondiscrimination in all its educational and employment activities. The District prohibits discrimination based on perceived or actual race; national or ethnic origin; color; sex; religion; age; sexual orientation; gender expression or identity; pregnancy; marital status; veteran’s status; familial status; economic status or source of income; mental or physical disability or perceived disability; or military service. 504 Coordinator: Marquita Guzman,mguzman@pps.net, 971-393-8633 ADA Coordinator: Jey Buno, jbuno@pps.net, 503-916-3360 Civil Rights Director: Dr. Bobby Cruz, bcruz@pps.net, 503-839-3660 Accessibility Statement Conflict/Complaint Resolution Process

Assistant Softball Coach - Wilsonville High School
This position will start on February 16, 2026.
The Assistant Softball Coach assists the Head Softball Coach in promoting an appreciation of physical fitness, teamwork, and sportsmanship. The Assistant Softball Coach assists in providing leadership and supervision for team and individual sports, and works closely with the other staff and administration.
The coach shall have completed the annual online required trainings as well as other West Linn-Wilsonville employment requirements.
Community and District Information: The West Linn-Wilsonville School District is nestled within two thriving cities, West Linn and Wilsonville, within the rural area of Clackamas County. Both communities have a strong legacy of support for their schools, music and arts endeavors, and the overall well-being of their patrons. The school district and surrounding communities have experienced steady, constant growth over the past three decades. The estimated student population of the District as of December 2023 is 9,076.
It is the policy of the West Linn-Wilsonville Board of Education and School District (WLWV) that no discrimination or harassment on the grounds of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, sexual orientation, age, marital status, veterans’ status, genetic information or disability exists in any of its programs, activities, or practices; and that there will be no discrimination or harassment against individuals or groups based on perceived or actual protected characteristics, or because of association with any person or group who is perceived to have protected characteristics. The District’s Compliance Officer/Title IX Coordinator is Shyla Waldern, who can be reached at 503-673-7000.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS at Henderson High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Henderson High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Henderson High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.Location: Henderson High School, West Chester, Pennsylvania
Job.CompanyDescription: West Chester Area School D. coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS position at Henderson High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Henderson High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the 2025-2026 - (Spring Supplemental) Assistant Coach - Girls Flag Football - HHS role at Henderson High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - ASST. Coach - Girls Lacrosse - PMS
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - ASST. Coach - Girls Lacrosse - PMS role at Peirce Middle School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - ASST. Coach - Girls Lacrosse - PMS coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Peirce Middle School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - ASST. Coach - Girls Lacrosse - PMS reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Peirce Middle School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - ASST. Coach - Girls Lacrosse - PMS may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - ASST. Coach - Girls Lacrosse - PMS monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - ASST. Coach - Girls Lacrosse - PMS must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Peirce Middle School.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track at Stetson Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Stetson Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Stetson Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Stetson Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track role at Stetson Middle School.
Job.Location: Stetson Middle School, West Chester, Pennsylvania

Job.JobDescription:
Head Coach Girls Junior Varsity Softball
Position Summary/Goal: The Head Coach will facilitate and entrance communication and collaboration between and among the Erie School District and parents, students, and community members. The Head Coach will promote a positive school culture and foster academic excellence and exemplify good character for the individual athlete. Furthermore, the Erie School District expects the Head Coach to be a positive role model, a mentor to student-athletes, and embrace all concepts of good citizenship.
Term of Employment: 12 month position Schools/Location: Erie High School
Reporting Relationships: High School Varsity Head Coach Reports to Athletic Director & Building Administrator May work on specific projects with program directors or building principals.
Qualifications: Head coaching experience at the high school or middle school level, minimum of 3 years' experience required. Evidence of leading a successful middle school or high school softball program with a winning record and post season coaching experience. Ability to transition student athletes to the next competitive level (ability to articulate concrete examples and procedures regarding the transition of student athletes to the next competitive level). The ability to design offensive and defensive strategies. Evidence of practice plans developed in prior coaching positions. Must possess strong interpersonal skills and communication skills. Urban student experience a plus. Possess a thorough understanding of all PIAA and NFHS rules appropriate to the sport. Must hold or obtain FBI, Criminal Check, and Child Abuse Clearances. Working knowledge of Erie School District policies, procedures, and organizational structure. Knowledge of current trends, tactics, strategies, and skills of the sport.
Special Requirements: Must complete all Coaching Education requirements of the PIAA and PDE. Work Environment: School and office with frequent travel between schools, and various locations within the Erie community. Occasional travel to relevant professional conferences and meetings outside the district.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities: Must monitor grades and conduct of student athletes. Implement the program philosophy created by Varsity Girls Softball Coaches. Attend all season practices, games, and tournaments. Develop and organize gym schedule with Athletic department for practices and games. Create and share practice schedule and phone list for players and parents. Create weekly practice plans and forward to High School Girls Varsity coach by Monday morning each week during season. Run 2 hour practices 4- 5 days a week (games are exception) & dedicate 1st hour of each practice to skills and player development. Maintain and review transportation schedule for away games. Instruct players in the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport. Organize and direct individual and small group practice activities/exercises as directed by the Head Varsity Girls Softball Coach. Assess skills of athletes, monitor athletes during competition and practice, and keep the Head Varsity Girls Softball Coach informed of the athletic performance of students. Participate in special activities to include parent nights, banquets, award nights, and pep assemblies. Perform support tasks such as distributing and maintaining eligibility forms, emergency data cards, and other related records. Assist in evaluating and choosing middle school team with coaches in the program. Organize events that crossover with Varsity program (i.e. team night at home varsity game). Organize and run junior varsity fundraisers for season tournaments, off-season leagues and team gear, etc. Host parent meeting before the first game. Maintain positive communication with athletes, families, community members, and district administration. Maintain positive communication with athletes, families, community members, and district administration. Collect and inventory equipment and uniforms.
Professionalism: Must possess the ability to be a team player. Must be cooperative, courteous, service oriented, and promote these characteristics with the team. Represent Erie's Public Schools with the highest level of ethical behavior and professional standards.
Off-Season Attend and work program fundraisers. Attend off-season area team camps and possible fall leagues. Organize off-season open gym/weight room sessions, practice plans, and instruction.
Other Duties Attend staff meetings, clinics and other professional activities to improve coaching performance. Perform any other related duties as assigned by the Head Softball Coach, Athletic Director & Principal or other appropriate administrator.
Evaluation: High School Girls Varsity Head Coach, Building Administrator, and Athletic Director This list is intended to be illustrative rather than complete and serves to show major duties and responsibilities and does not express or imply that these are the only duties to be performed by the incumbent in this position. The employee will be required to perform any other position-related duties requested by the supervisor.
Job.Experience: Head coaching experience at the high school or middle school level, minimum of 3 years' experience required.
Job.CompanyDescription: Erie City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
Our Human Resources Team at the Greenville County School District is dedicated to advancing student achievement by recruiting and employing the highest qualified staff for our schools and to serve those with whom we work.
Summary: Athletic positions require someone with proven decision-making skills, a track record of initiative and effort and a commitment to young people and education. Our jobs require a “people person” that indicates through actions a personality that is conducive to positive interactions with students, staff and parents.
To view the job description for each type of athletic coach, click here on the Athletics Position Descriptions. Click here on the Supplements for Athletics link to see athletics supplementary salary schedule.
Coaching positions require the following Continuing Education Requirements: - GCS Safety Videos Required Annually: - Bloodborne Pathogen Exposure Prevention - FERPA: Confidentiality of Records - GCS – Title IX & Safe Schools - GCS – Code of Ethics & Social Media - GCS – Information Security Mgmt System - GCS – Safety Training - GCS – Mandated Reporter - Greenville Energy Conservation - Hazard Communication: Right to Understand - Health Emergencies: Overview - Sexual Harassment: Staff to Staff - GCS – Active Shooter Training - NFHS Courses Required Annually: - Concussion in Sport - Heat Illness Prevention - Sudden Cardiac Arrest - Protecting Students from Abuse - NFHS Accredited Interscholastic Coach – Required Once for all New Head Coaches - Fundamentals of Coaching ($60) - Football Coaches - Heads UP Football Safety Coach Certification - Strength Coaches - NHSSCA – Must be certified to receive the strength supplement - Training Required in 1st Year then Every 2 Years: - CPR – The GCS CPR certification process is offered in a blended learning format, which means you complete an online course FIRST, and then follow it with a hands-on skills evaluation session within a maximum of 60 days after online course completion. - AED - First Aid for Adults, Children and Infants
Greenville County Schools does not discriminate on the basis of age, race, sex, color, disability, religion, or national origin in its dealings with employees, students, the general public, applicants for employment, educational programs, activities, or access to its facilities.

Job.JobTitle: MAULDIN HIGH SCHOOL DANCE TEAM COACH 26-27 (JOB ID: 26358)
Job.JobDescription:
The MAULDIN HIGH SCHOOL DANCE TEAM COACH 26 at Mauldin High is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the MAULDIN HIGH SCHOOL DANCE TEAM COACH 26 are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Mauldin High use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The MAULDIN HIGH SCHOOL DANCE TEAM COACH 26 recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the MAULDIN HIGH SCHOOL DANCE TEAM COACH 26 collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The MAULDIN HIGH SCHOOL DANCE TEAM COACH 26 maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Mauldin High. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.Location: Mauldin High, 701 E Butler Rd, Mauldin, SC 29662

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Track Coach - Berkeley High
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Track Coach - Berkeley High at Berkeley High is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Track Coach - Berkeley High is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Berkeley High, the 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Track Coach - Berkeley High helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Track Coach - Berkeley High may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Berkeley High well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Assistant Varsity Track Coach - Berkeley High follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Position Type: Athletics/Extra-curricular/Athletic Coach Date Posted: 7/1/2025 Location: Lexington County School District One Position Title: Coach Department: Student Services Reports To: Principal/Athletic Director FLSA Status: Not applicable REQUIRED EDUCATION and/or EXPERIENCE: Experience as a participant or coach of the assigned sport; or any equivalent combination of training and experience which provides the required knowledge, skills and abilities CERTIFICATES, LICENSES, REGISTRATIONS: Must have current government issued identification TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT: Seasonal part-time Athletics Salary Schedule The terms of employment detailed in this job description are based on full time employment during the school year. Conditions of employment may be adjusted for part time employees or individuals who are hired for less than an entire school year. GENERAL SUMMARY: Under general supervision of the athletic director, instructs students in a sport to obtain a high skill level, an appreciation of discipline and sportsmanship, and increased self-esteem. ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: Supports and upholds the mission, vision and strategic goals of Lexington County School District One towards increased outcomes for students. Interacts, communicates and collaborates with all stakeholders effectively. Establishes a safe, supportive, positive and productive working and learning environment. Operates general office and technology equipment needed for daily activities. Maintains confidentiality regarding all employee and student information. Participates in all professional meetings and training sessions as required. Requests and maintains materials needed for daily responsibilities and essential functions; provides for safe storage and proper use of all tools, equipment and materials. Explains and demonstrates use of apparatus and equipment. Explains and demonstrates principles, techniques, and methods of regulating movement of the body, hands, or feet to achieve proficiency in activity. Plans and schedules a regular program of practice; observes students during practice to detect and correct mistakes. Explains and enforces safety rules and regulations. Oversees the safety conditions of the facility or area in which assigned sport is conducted. Explains methods of keeping score. Organizes and conducts competitions and tournaments. Works closely with the athletic director in scheduling intramural and interscholastic contests and in assuring adequate publicity for the assigned sport. Establishes and enforces performance criteria for eligibility in interscholastic competition in each assigned sport. Enforces discipline and sportsmanlike behavior at all times; establishes and oversees penalties for breach of such standards by individual students. Recommends purchase of equipment, supplies, and uniforms as appropriate to the athletic director. Assumes responsibility as assigned for maintaining equipment, storage areas, and playing areas for assigned sport. Assumes responsibility for students at all times during the school day and supervises students on the grounds as assigned by the principal. Meets with parents, administrators and school counselors as needed to discuss student performance, activities, etc. Performs other job-related duties as assigned SUPERVISORY RESPONSIBILITY: Responsible for athletic equipment and facilities. Supervises students participating in sport being coached. OTHER SKILLS and ABILITIES: Ability to perform duties with awareness of all district requirements and Lexington County School District One Board policies. Must be able to access reliable transportation. Knowledge of the policies, procedures, and activities of the school district which pertain to the specific duties and responsibilities of the position. Knowledge of school policies, procedures, and operations. Ability to demonstrate proper maintenance, safe operation, and utilization of equipment, materials, and supplies used in daily activities. Ability to maintain high standards of accuracy in exercising duties. Ability to anticipate work to be completed and to complete work without the need for direct supervision. Ability to maintain confidentiality of employee and student records and information. Ability to interact and communicate in an effective and professional manner with supervisors, co-workers, teachers, students, and the general public.
Job.Experience: Experience as a participant or coach of the assigned sport

Job.JobDescription: Position Type: High School Teacher/High School Teacher/Head Football Coach Date Posted: 12/18/2025 Location: White Knoll High School Date Available: 02/02/2026 Closing Date: 01/09/2026 Position Title: High School Teacher/Head Athletic Coach Department: Instructional Services Reports To: Principal FLSA Status: Exempt REQUIRED EDUCATION and/or EXPERIENCE: Bachelor’s degree in relevant teaching content or related area of discipline with previous student teaching experience; or equivalent combination of training and experience which provides the required knowledge, skills and abilities Assigned athletic coaching experience at the high school level (or higher level) CERTIFICATES, LICENSES, REGISTRATIONS: Valid SC Teaching License (any applicable area) Must have current government issued identification TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT: 8 Hours/190 Days Certified Salary Schedule (plus Relevant Coaching Supplements) The terms of employment detailed in this job description are based on full time employment during the school year. Conditions of employment adjusted for part time employees or individuals who are hired for less than an entire school year. GENERAL SUMMARY: Under general supervision, plans, instructs and assesses student learning through standards-based curricula for assigned courses and to assist in other school programs as assigned. Additionally, as Head Athletic Coach, the employee will be responsible for leading and managing the school's assigned athletic program, focusing on developing student-athletes both on and off the field, court or track as well as fostering a positive and disciplined team culture. ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: Supports and upholds the mission, vision and strategic goals of Lexington County School District One towards increased outcomes for students. Interacts, communicates and collaborates with all stakeholders effectively. Establishes a safe, supportive, positive and productive working and learning environment. Operates general office and technology equipment needed for daily activities. Participates in all professional meetings and training sessions as required. Requests and maintains materials needed for daily responsibilities and essential functions; provides for safe storage and proper use of all tools, equipment and materials. Demonstrates a variety of appropriate teaching skills to foster independent, creative, critical thinkers and problem solvers. Designs and facilitates engaging, high level, sophisticated learning experiences and applications appropriate to prepare students for a 21st century global, knowledge-based society. Teaches concepts and skills in the relevant subject matter that facilitate learning and contribute to students' academic and social/emotional development; administers the classroom curriculum for physical education and/or health as prescribed by the state standards. Assists in the planning, organization, and implementation of programs as assigned. Demonstrates and evaluates the effectiveness of both formative and summative assessments; monitors student progression in classwork and assists students with all phases of the course; observes student work to make criticisms and corrections; evaluates contributions in teams. Collaborates with school and district personnel to evaluate effectiveness of curriculum and make suggestions for improvement. Networks with school personnel regarding scheduling issues. Prepares various records and forms such as lesson plans, daily and weekly activity plans, assessments, material requisitions, discipline reports, etc. Participates in faculty and professional meetings, educational conferences, and teacher training workshops. Organizes classrooms and other settings for daily instruction. Provide leadership to the assigned athletic program, fostering a positive and motivating environment for both players and assistant coaches Develop and communicate a clear vision for the team’s success Implement effective coaching strategies to enhance players’ skills, both individually and as a team Monitor and assess the performances of players, providing constructive feedback and guidance for improvement Plan and conduct regular team practices, focusing on skill development, game strategies, and physical conditioning Create a well-organized and efficient practice schedule that maximizes player development Develop and implement effective game plans, making strategic decisions during contests Analyze opponents’ strengths and weaknesses to exploit opportunities for success Foster a sense of teamwork, camaraderie, and sportsmanship among players Encourage positive communication and collaboration on and off the field, court or track Stay informed and in compliance with all relevant South Carolina High School League rules and regulations Actively engage with the community, building support for the assigned athletic program through events, fundraisers, and outreach Operates general office and technology equipment needed for daily activities. Maintains confidentiality regarding all employee and student information.
Job.Experience: Bachelor’s degree in relevant teaching content or related area of discipline with previous student teaching experience; or equivalent combination of training and experience which provides the required knowledge, skills and abilities Assigned athletic coaching experience at the high school level (or higher level)

Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach at Nation Ford High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Nation Ford High School, the Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Nation Ford High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Varsity Football - Defensive Assistant Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.Location: Nation Ford High School - Fort Mill, South Carolina
Job.SalaryRange: Stipend: $6,800, Compensated According to the FMSD High School Athletic Supplemental Salary Schedule
